Regional—Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA)

Strengthening  Regulatory  Capacity  for  Information 
and  Communication  Technology  Development  in  the 
Pacific  
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Pacific Regional Digital Strategy calls for stronger regional cooperation among the 
Pacific island countries by sharing scarce regulatory resources and harmonizing legislation and 
the regulatory environment.1 Delegates at the Pacific Regional Information and Communication 
Technology (ICT) Ministerial Meeting in Nuku’alofa in June 2010 endorsed the establishment of 
the Pacific ICT Regulatory Resource Centre (PIRRC). They also agreed to establish the Centre 
Working Group (CWG) to develop the governance framework of the PIRRC.2 In April 2011, the 
ICT ministers from the Pacific Islands Forum member countries endorsed the establishment of 
the PIRRC as an operating unit under the University of the South Pacific (USP), its governance, 
and membership arrangements, and requested development partner support for the PIRRC.3  
 
2.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) consulted with representatives from CWG, the 
World Bank, USP, and the Japan International Cooperation Agency on the proposed technical 
assistance (TA) scope and implementation arrangement. The CWG, representing the Pacific 
island  countries,  concurred  with  the  TA’s  impact,  outcome  and  outputs,  implementation 
arrangement, financing plan, and consultant terms of reference. The design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  ICT supports economic growth and social development.  Recent quantitative studies 
indicate that an increase in ICT penetration has a positive impact on economic growth, and the 
impact is larger in low- and middle-income countries than in developed countries.4 The impact 
ICT  has  on  improving  education  and  health  service  delivery,  disaster  risk  reduction, 
administrative services, etc., is well documented around the world. Pacific developing member 
countries  (DMCs)  should  harness  ICT  to  overcome  remoteness  and  dispersed  population, 
which result in diseconomies of scale.  
 
4.  Market  liberalization  and  consequent  competition  in the  telecommunication  and ICT 
sectors have expanded service coverage, improved the quality, and lowered the prices of ICT 
services in some Pacific DMCs. Many countries with monopoly operators experience slow 
improvement in the sector. Even for a liberalized market, successful competition in the ICT 
sector requires government involvement to (i) apply rules and regulations equally and impartially, 
(ii) ensure appropriate investment signals through clear policy directions and measures, and (iii) 
protect consumers. These are the areas where ICT regulations can improve sector performance. 
 
5.  Regulatory  systems  in the  Pacific  are  relatively  new  or  immature.  Fiji,  Papua  New 
Guinea, Samoa, Solomon Islands, Tonga, and Vanuatu have liberalized the telecommunications 
market and, with the exception of Tonga, have established independent regulators. Most of 
them have a legal framework for market liberalization but do not have elaborated policy and 
regulatory  rules  to  implement.  Before  liberalization,  regulatory  functions  were  imbedded  in 
government ministries and were concerned primarily with technical aspects, such as spectrum 
management and standardization of user apparatus. Competition policy, dispute mediation and 
resolution, public consultation, and consumer protection are new areas for Pacific regulators. In

countries without an independent regulator, a ministry that is responsible for the sector policy 
frequently develops regulations and monitors compliance. Monopoly operators—often owned by 
the government—were allowed to have quasi-regulatory powers, such as control of spectrum 
and  a  national  numbering  plan.  In  these  countries,  both  the  legal  framework  for  more 
independent  regulatory  functions  and  the  regulatory  body’s  institutional  capacity  need 
improvement. The ICT sector is changing rapidly due to innovations in technology and business 
practice, which aggravate the challenges faced by Pacific DMC regulators with limited human 
and financial resources.5  
 
6.  In summary, regulators in the Pacific face challenges in (i) market liberalization (non-
exclusive  carrier  licenses,  spectrum  management,  interconnection  arrangement,  and  cost-
based pricing); (ii) universal service schemes; and (iii) institutional development for independent 
operation.  The  regulatory  capacity  becomes  more  important  in  countries  with  monopoly 
operators because their regulators have to improve market performance through policy and 
regulatory instruments in the absence of competition.  
 
7.  The PIRRC was established to help the Pacific DMCs address these challenges. The 
PIRRC aims to become a regional telecommunications and ICT regulatory support facility with a 
range of functions including (i) supporting information sharing and industry data collection, (ii) 
improving awareness of sector performance across the region, (iii) providing direct assistance to 
regulators and policy makers, and (iv) assisting member countries in building their regulatory 
capacity and adopting best practice principles and supporting legislation that is consistent with 
international experience.        
 
8.  The Pacific Region Infrastructure Facility, through the World Bank, has provided $1.3 
million to support the establishment of the PIRRC and its operations at a basic level of service 
for 2011—2013.6 The PIRRC will collect nominal annual membership fees from each member 
country.  It  expects  7—10  countries  to  become  paying  members  by  2016  and  for  these 
membership fees to cover most of its non-staff operational costs. However, a funding gap will 
remain in both staff and non-staff costs (training, travel, short-term consultants, etc.) for the first 
3 years of operation. Without additional funding, the PIRRC will be unable to effectively respond 
to the surging demand from Pacific DMCs.7 The credibility of the PIRRC depends on its ability to 
provide timely, demand-driven, technically sound, and customized support until the desired 
regulatory framework and practices are established. Therefore, it is advisable for the PIRRC to 
have more resources to provide technical advisory and capacity development services to meet 
the high demand of existing and emerging regulators in the Pacific DMCs. Readily accessible 
advisory services are relatively more important for smaller island countries with weak regulatory 
capacity than for countries with independent regulators.  
 
9.  The  TA  will  augment  other  development  partners’  assistance  through  the  PIRRC, 
enhancing PIRRC’s services to Pacific DMCs by mobilizing an advisor and technical experts. 
The  TA  will  also  help  the  PIRRC  build  awareness  about  the  benefits  of  improved  ICT

3 
regulations among the general public and policy makers (especially parliamentarians) through 
the PIRRC website, the mass media (i.e., internet, newspapers, radio, and TV), and in-country 
events. This will ensure that the general public, civil society, governments, and parliaments are 
able to create the demand for better ICT regulation.  
 
10.  The  TA  is  consistent  with  ADB’s  Pacific  Approach,  2010—2014,  which  identifies 
transport and ICT as an operational priority.8 The TA will strengthen the technical advisory 
service of the PIRRC so it can be established as a sustainable regional knowledge hub that 
contributes to regional cooperation and helps to coordinate regulatory standards in cross-border 
issues in the ICT sector. Improvements in ICT policy and regulations will also create enabling 
environment for the private sector. Responding to the Pacific DMCs’ demand for improved 
connectivity  through  ICT,  ADB  has  been  increasing  investment  in  ICT  infrastructure  and 
applications  in  the  region.9 The  performance  of  ADB’s  investment  projects  can  be  further 
enhanced by improved regulatory environment.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
11.  The  TA  will  deliver  ICT  regulatory  advisory  services  through  the  PIRRC  that  will 
contribute  to  (i)  sharing  experiences  and  international  best  practices  frequently,  (ii) 
strengthening the capacity of ICT regulatory bodies and policy makers, (iii) providing demand 
driven  advisory  services,  and  (iv)  raising  broad-based  awareness  to  demand  better  ICT 
regulations. The TA will provide two consultants—an ICT regulation technical advisor and a 
media relations and communications officer—and several short-term technical experts and will 
fund awareness-raising events. These actions will augment the existing PIRRC resources and 
increase the relevance and effectiveness of its advisory services. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
12.  The impact of the TA will be that the population of the Pacific islands has access to ICT 
services at affordable prices. The TA outcome will be that the PIRRC provides demand-driven 
ICT regulatory advisory services based on international best practices.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  The TA activities will be guided by the governance and working arrangement of the 
PIRRC as agreed by the CWG representing the Pacific DMCs. The TA will enhance the quality 
of advisory services and widen the available range of services by augmenting the existing 
PIRRC resources. Key activities will include:  
 
(i)  Support to develop a PIRRC business plan for sustainable operation. The PIRRC 
was established with the support of the Pacific Region Infrastructure Facility, 
which will last until 2013. Capacity development takes more time, while the ICT 
sector is rapidly changing in terms of technology and business practices. The 
Pacific island countries would need continued services beyond the development 
partner support. Therefore, the PIRRC needs to develop a business plan to 
develop  mechanisms  to  ensure  sustainable  and  continuous  support  to  its

members. The TA will support the PIRRC and its members to develop and agree 
on a business plan.  
 
(ii)  Support to publish and disseminate best practices in ICT regulations. The TA will 
provide technical experts to help the PIRRC develop publications (booklets and 
policy statements) on ICT regulations, especially related to cost-based retail and 
wholesale tariff, quality-of-service monitoring, spectrum pricing, and monitoring, 
etc. These publications will inform Pacific island country regulators about the 
cutting edge practices that can be adapted to their environment. The TA aims to 
publish  at  least  two  information  packages  and  four  best-practice  statements 
about ICT regulation and implementing rules.  
 
(iii)  Support to build a community of practice among ICT regulators and experts. 
Pacific regulators are new to the job and are having difficulties working in a 
regulatory and sector environment that is very different from other parts of world. 
The TA will support the PIRRC to develop mentoring and coaching relationships 
with the existing and future regulators in the Pacific by making expert advice 
available  and  building  a  community  of  practice  among  peer  regulators  and 
experts to encourage sharing experiences and lessons.  
 
(iv)  Support to develop a media strategy and to implement a media campaign for 
public awareness of the benefits of reforming the ICT sector. There is increasing 
demand for cheaper and better quality communication services, but the general 
public has little awareness of the importance of good ICT regulations for bringing 
about cheaper and better quality services. The TA will support the PIRRC and 
Pacific regulators to develop a media strategy and implement a media campaign 
to increase public awareness so that the general public can call for ICT sector 
reform and regulatory changes.   
 
(v)  Support  to  identify  ICT  cross-border  issues  and  facilitate  discussion  among 
member countries for regional cooperation. Considering the small size and the 
limited human resources of the Pacific island countries, there is a large need for 
more  regional  cooperation  in  many  areas  including  ICT.  With  businesses, 
governments, and individuals increasing their use of ICT, there is a need for a 
regional  approach,  especially  for  cross-border  issues  such  as  electronic 
transactions, cyber security, interconnection, mobile roaming, etc. The TA will 
provide technical experts to identify key issues for member countries to discuss 
and explore a regional solution to resolve at least one cross-border issue by early 
2014.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The Pacific DMCs have requested ADB to finance $750,000 equivalent. The TA will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The Pacific 
DMC  governments  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  staff  time,  office 
accommodation, and other in-kind contributions. Cost estimates and the financing plan are in 
Appendix 2.

5 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The TA implementation will commence on 1 December 2011 and be completed on 31 
May 2014. ADB will be the executing agency, and the Pacific Department will be the focal point 
for  TA  management.  USP  will  assume  the  role  of  implementing  agency.  As  the  host 
organization  of  the  PIRRC,  USP  will  ensure  the  PIRRC  have  adequate  office  facility  and 
organizational support for the TA-funded consultants and activities.  
 
16.  The TA will provide 25 person-months of international consultant with expertise in ICT 
policy, regulation, and industry practices and with experience providing advisory services to 
member countries. It will also provide 15 person-months of national consultant with skills and 
experience in public and media relations and communications. In addition, it will provide 11 
person-months  of  international  or  national  consultants  specialized  in  specific  areas  of  ICT 
regulations. Individual consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with ADB's Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference 
for the consultants are in Appendix 3. An advance payment facility will be established to allow 
the PIRRC, with the support of USP, to organize awareness-raising events. Disbursements 
under the TA  will  be made  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis for 
Strengthening  Regulatory  Capacity  for  Information  and  Communication  Technology 
Development in the Pacific, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  General 
 
1.  The  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  provide  (i)  25  person-months  of  an  international 
consultant with expertise in information and communication technologies (ICT) regulation and 
ICT industry practices, and experience in providing advisory services to developing country 
agencies; (ii) 15 person-months of national consultants with skills and experience in public and 
media relations and communications; and (iii) 11 person-months of international or national 
short-term experts depending on the specific technical areas required by member countries.  
 
2.  The consultants will be located in the Pacific ICT Regulatory Resource Centre (PIRRC) 
at the University of the South Pacific (USP) and will work closely with the PIRRC steering 
committee,  management  committee,  staff,  and  experts  from  other  organizations  and 
development partners. The consultants will report to ADB as the executing agency and USP as 
the implementing agency of the TA. The outline terms of reference described below set the 
overall objectives and scope of work. Long-term consultants’ detailed annual work plan and 
performance  targets  will  be  developed  in  consultation  with  the  PIRRC  steering  and 
management committees.    
 
B.   Scope of Consulting Services 
 
1.  ICT Regulation Technical Advisor (international, 25 person-months, 
intermittent) 
 
3.  Under  the  overall  supervision  of  the  PIRRC  director  and  guided  by  the  steering 
committee, the ICT regulation technical advisor will be responsible for providing technical inputs 
on telecommunications and ICT regulatory issues in close cooperation with member country 
regulators and policy makers. Specifically, the advisor will do the following:  
 
(i)  build up an up-to-date understanding of the current status of ICT development in 
the Pacific and the individual member countries and identify challenges and 
opportunities in ICT regulations, focusing on technical aspects; 
(ii)  establish  contacts  and  regular  communications  with  the  member  country 
regulators and policy makers, as well as other relevant regional entities and 
development partners active in ICT regulation; 
(iii)  establish good rapport and communication channels (email, instant messaging, 
etc.) with the member country regulators and play the role of mentor; 
(iv)  develop  a  community  of  practice  or  knowledge  sharing  group  among  ICT 
regulators and experts and moderate the discussions;   
(v)  provide advice to the member country regulators on the latest developments in 
international and regional best practices in the ICT sector and regulatory aspects 
in the following areas but not limited to1: 
(a)  competition (anti-competitive behaviors and remedies); 
(b)  interconnection  (interconnection  pricing,  mobile  roaming,  cross-border 
interconnection, dispute resolution, etc.); 
(c)  internet  (voice  over  internet  protocol,  internet  related  interconnection, 
network access, internet exchange points, etc.);

topics and best practices statements (under the direction of the PIRRC director 
and in collaboration with short-term consultants and the media relations and 
communications officer);  
(vii)  provide inputs to PIRRC’s regulatory capacity development program;  
(viii)  respond  to  the  specific  needs  of  the  PIRRC  and  its  member  countries—in 
consultation with the PIRRC director—and develop terms of reference for short-
term technical consultants and forward to ADB for recruitment;  
(ix)  control the quality of short-term consultants’ outputs;  
(x)  provide  guidance  to  the  media  relations  and  communications  officer’s 
deliverables  including  press  releases,  op-eds,  featured  stories,  and  briefing

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
materials for the general public, civil society organizations, media, government 
officials, and parliament members; and 
(xi)  provide an individual work plan (annual and quarterly with performance targets) 
and progress report (quarterly) to the PIRRC director and ADB. The individual 
work plan should refer to the centre’s annual work plan and be endorsed by ADB 
and the steering committee.  
 
2.  Media Relations and Communications Officer (national, 15 person-months, 
intermittent) 
 
4.  Under the supervision of the PIRRC director, the media relations and communications 
officer will be responsible for implementing PIRRC’s communications strategy and work plan, 
maintaining close relationships with regional and local media and civil society organizations in 
member countries. The officer will be particularly responsible for: 
 
(i)  developing a communications strategy and annual plan for the PIRRC for the 
steering committee’s approval. The communication strategy will contain effective 
approaches for different audiences;  
(ii)  developing  press  releases,  op-eds,  featured  stories,  media  briefings,  and 
information sessions on (a) the ICT sector; (b) regulatory initiatives aimed at 
sector performance improvement; and (c) PIRRC support, focusing on the overall 
benefits for the general public. Audience-specific materials will be developed for 
civil  society  organizations,  government  officials,  and  parliamentarians  as 
necessary;   
(iii)  monitoring regional and local media for coverage on the ICT sector;  
(iv)  establishing contacts with member country ICT regulators for media relations and 
providing relevant advice;  
(v)  establishing and maintaining contacts with regional and local media and relevant 
civil society groups;  
(vi)  liaising and coordinating with the International Telecommunications Union, USP, 
Secretariat of Pacific Community, other regional organizations, and development 
partners to leverage their regional and in-country events for media coverage and 
outlets for the effective and efficient delivery of the work plan; 
(vii)  managing the contents of the PIRRC website and mailing list for effective and up-
to-date dissemination of PIRRC knowledge products and news; and  
(viii)  providing assistance to the PIRRC publication and dissemination efforts. 
 
3.  Other Experts (international/national, 11 person-months, intermittent) 
 
5.  The  TA  will  provide  approximately  11  person-months  of  intermittent  and  short-term 
international  and  national  consultants  with  different  expertise  in  varied  areas  of  regulatory 
themes and functions. Specific consulting requirements will be defined further based on the 
PIRRC and annual work plans. Short-term consultants to enhance PIRRC management can be 
considered in the areas of evaluation, business plan development, etc. Their terms of reference 
will be developed by the PIRRC director and the ICT regulation technical advisor and sent to 
ADB for the recruitment process.
